translated: The Book of Conditional Relations🔽The Chapter on the Pairs of Doctrinal Ideas

original: Dhammānulomapaccanīya (3), Dukapaṭṭhānapāḷi (2)🔽14.21. Sārammaṇaduka🔽Sārammaṇaṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca nasārammaṇo dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā … tīṇi.🔽Anārammaṇaṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca naanārammaṇo dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā … tīṇi.🔽Sārammaṇañca anārammaṇañca dhammaṁ paṭicca nasārammaṇo dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā … tīṇi. (Saṅkhittaṁ.)
analyzed: dhamma anuloma paccanīya  sa ārammaṇa duka  sa ārammaṇam dhammam paṭicca na sa ārammaṇaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā tīṇi  anārammaṇam dhammam paṭicca na anārammaṇaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā tīṇi  sa ārammaṇam ca anārammaṇam ca dhammam paṭicca na sa ārammaṇaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā tīṇi
translated: The Doctrinal Idea of Having an Object🔽With a state that has an object as condition there arises a state that has no object. With a state that has no object as condition there arises a state that has no object. With a state that has an object and a state that has no object as condition there arises a state that has no object. (Abbreviated.)

original: Hetuyā nava, ārammaṇe tīṇi, adhipatiyā pañca …pe… aññamaññe cha …pe… purejāte āsevane ekaṁ …pe… avigate nava. (Sabbattha vitthāro.)
analyzed: hetuyā nava ārammaṇe tīṇi adhipatiyā pañca pe aññamaññe cha pe purejāte āsevane ekam pe avigate nava sabbattha vitthāro
translated: In the cause there are nine; in the object there are three; in the predominance there are five. … In the mutual there are six. … In the prenascent and in the postnascent there is one. … In the unprompted there are nine. (In all cases the exposition should be expanded.)
